Kiev has so far not admitted involvement in the attack on Saturday, which sent massive plumes of smoke and flames into the air when a blast damaged one of the key supply routes for Moscow's faltering military campaign in Ukr…

entry.title: Austrian president secures re-election in first round, projections show
entry.summary: VIENNA (Reuters) - Austrian President Alexander Van der Bellen secured a second six-year term in office by obtaining more than 50% of the vote in an election on Sunday to avoid a runoff, initial projections issued soon after voting closed showed. A projection by pollster SORA for national broadcaster ORF based on a partial vote count put Van der Bellen, a 78-year-old former leader of the Greens, on 54.6% with a margin of error of 2.1 percentage points. His nearest rival was far-right Freedom Party candidate Walter Rosenkranz on 18.9%. (Reporting by Francois Murphy; Editing by Susan Fenton)

entry.title: Hurricane Julia hits Nicaragua with high winds
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Hurricane Julia slammed into Nicaragua on Sunday carrying top winds of up to 85 miles per hour (140 kph) and a storm surge, the U.S. National Hurricane Center said, warning of dangerous weather in the coming days across the region. The storm made landfall early on Sunday near Laguna de Perlas, the NHC said. By 5 a.m. (0900 GMT) it was around 30 miles (50 km) north-northwest of Bluefields. The hurricane was expected to gradually weaken as it crosses Nicaragua, emerging over the eastern Pacific by Sunday night. It was forecast to move near or along the Pacific coasts of Honduras, El Salvador, and Guatemala on Monday and Monday night, the NHC said. "Life-threatening flash floods and mudslides possible from heavy rains over Central America and Southern Mexico through early next week," the center said. (Writing by Frances Kerry; editing by Barbara Lewis)

entry.title: Mysterious drop in loon population prompts cross-border collaborations in North America
entry.summary: Loons are having fewer and smaller chicks, which are less likely to survive. Most surprisingly, young, non-breeding adults are also dramatically in decline — but no one knows why. Volunteers from Canada and the United States are on a quest for answers.

entry.title: The US should not ‘overestimate the divisions inside of Russia,’ former ambassador says
entry.summary: Even some of the Russian leader's closest advisers don't know what Vladimir Putin is thinking, according to former US Ambassador to Russia John Tefft. He has spent plenty of time in the room with Putin himself.

entry.title: Maine’s lobster industry is still feeling the effects of the trade war with China
entry.summary: As US-China relations continue to deteriorate over China’s messaging on Taiwan, the Biden administration recently announced it won’t remove tariffs on Chinese goods put in place by former President Donald Trump. The news is a blow to businesses that do substantial business with China.

entry.title: Colombia and Venezuela reopen shared border after years of closure
entry.summary: Residents from Colombia and Venezuela turned out in large numbers last week to welcome the reopening of their shared border to vehicles. Two commercial trucks, covered with the respective flags of each country, crossed the border point, marking the end of seven years of closure.

entry.title: ‘It will be a challenge’: Lula, Bolsonaro head to runoffs in tight Brazil elections
entry.summary: Brazil’s former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva was expected to cruise to a huge victory on Sunday. But the final result showed President Jair Bolsonaro just a handful of points behind. This means weeks of intense campaigning ahead of runoffs at the end of the month.

entry.title: Indonesian police probe tear gas firing at soccer match
entry.summary: An investigation is underway after 125 people were killed during a stampede after police fired tear gas at a soccer match in East Java’s Malang city in Indonesia.

entry.title: From the Archives, 1957: Cold War intensifies as Russia launches Sputnik
entry.summary: 65 years ago, Russia’s launched the first man-made satellite, signalling the dawn of the Space Age. Sputnik’s launch wounded America’s “national ego” and was likened to a “bloodless Pearl Harbour”.

entry.title: Russia has annexed more of Ukraine. What does that mean and what happens now?
entry.summary: Ukraine’s army is winning back territory almost as fast as Russia claims to have taken it over. How are the latest twists in the Ukraine crisis unfolding? And why is everyone talking about nukes?

entry.summary: WASHINGTON: Former President Donald Trump's administration has not turned over all presidential records and the National Archives will consult with the Justice Department on whether to move to get them back, the agency has told Congress. A congressional panel on Sep 13 sought an urgent review by the Nation

entry.title: MPs warned against tax cut rebellion as Truss concedes ‘communication mistakes’
entry.summary: The new prime minister distanced herself from her government’s controversial tax policy, describing it as a decision made by the chancellor.

entry.title: Commentary: Why has my cold dragged on so long? Could it be something more serious?
entry.summary: Do I have a cold or flu? Antibiotics do not work when we have a cold, and a cough often lasts beyond the actual viral infection, says this lecturer.

entry.summary: NASA’s Artemis project to fly to the Moon has revived the idea of crewed missions to Venus – Earth’s “evil twin” planet – to prepare for more complex, crewed missions to Mars. This physics professor says it would be of little value.

The disease killed about 10,000 people through a 2010 outbreak

entry.summary: SOFIA: Bulgaria's GERB party of ex-Prime Minister Boyko Borissov looked set for a narrow win in Sunday's (Oct 2) election, the fourth in less two years, as voters sought predictability from a former leader amid steep inflation and the war in Ukraine. Exit polls by Gallup International and Alpha Research sh

entry.summary: OUAGADOUGOU: Burkina Faso's self-declared military leader Captain Ibrahim Traore has accepted a conditional resignation offered by President Paul-Henri Damiba to avoid further violence after Friday's coup, religious and traditional leaders said on Sunday (Oct 2). According to the deal, announced at a press

entry.summary: Russia’s loss of the eastern city of Lyman, which it had been using as a transport and logistics hub, is a new blow to the Kremlin.

entry.summary: MEXICO CITY : Hurricane Orlene barreled toward Mexico's southwestern coast as a dangerous Category 3 storm and is expected to dump torrential rains even as it is forecast to weaken in the coming days, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said on Sunday. Orlene, which is packing maximum sustained winds near

entry.title: ‘Lesbian spring break’: Dinah Shore festival shines in a dark time for women
entry.summary: With its “no judgment” ethos and legacy of inclusion, the world’s biggest queer women’s gathering has become a safe space for a whole new generation.

entry.summary: BRASILIA: Brazil's electoral authorities began counting votes on Sunday (Oct 2) in the first round of the country's most polarized election in decades, with leftist Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva favoured to beat right-wing incumbent Jair Bolsonaro. entry.summary: KYIV: Ukrainian troops said they had taken the key bastion of Lyman in occupied eastern Ukraine, a stinging defeat that prompted a close ally of Russian President Vladimir Putin to call f

entry.title: US conservative group backpedals on pro-Russia tweet as some back Putin
entry.summary: Prominent Republicans are digging in against American support for Ukraine despite Russia’s threats to use nuclear weapons.

entry.summary: In one corner was the chocolate bunny wrapped in gold foil by a German discount retailer Lidl, in the other one made by a venerable Swiss chocolatier.

entry.summary: The rapid growth of dark data raises significant questions about the efficiency of current digital practices, say two professors.

entry.summary: Hundreds of thousands of Russians are fleeing their country in order to avoid Russia’s first mobilisation since the second world war. They must be given protection, says a law professor.

entry.title: Funeral in Mashahd for two people killed by rioters
entry.summary: People in the Iranian city of Mashhad have held a funeral ceremony for two people killed by rioters in recent days in Khorasan Razavi Province.

entry.summary: Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister says Riyadh intends to establish close and friendly relationship with Iran since representatives from both states have held several rounds of talks.

entry.summary: US President Joe Biden has decided to rescind Afghanistan's designation as a "major non-NATO ally", the White House has announced.

entry.title: Iran’s Interior Ministry: Violent riots will only result in fear among public
entry.summary: Iran’s Interior Ministry has issued a statement in reaction to the recent unrest in the country following the death of an Iranian woman in police custody, advising people to stay away from violent rioters.

entry.title: EU’s chief says proposals to revive nuclear deal still on table
entry.summary: The EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell has stated that proposals to revive the 2015 Iran nuclear deal are still on the table.

entry.summary: The new school year in Iran started earlier on Saturday after two years of coronavirus pandemic that closed educational centers.

entry.summary: Iran’s interior minister says definitive medical evidence suggests Mahsa Amini, who died in the custody of morality police last week, had not been subjected to beating by those in charge of the detention facility.

entry.summary: The Iranian president says his government will listen to the complaints of the protesters who took to the streets after the death of a young Iranian woman in police custody, but will not yield to civil commotion and acts of vandalism by rioters.

entry.summary: The Austrian foreign minister has expressed his country’s readiness to play a constructive role in resolving the remaining issues with the International Atomic Energy Agency in line with efforts to conclude the Vienna talks.

entry.title: Iran FM: Swedish court ruling against Iran national illegal
entry.summary: The Iranian foreign minister says the verdict issued by a Swedish court against former Iranian official Hamid Nouri lacked any credibility and legal qualifications.

entry.summary: The Iranian foreign ministry has summoned the Swedish charge d’affaires in Tehran following the attack on the embassy of the Islamic Republic in Stockholm on Friday.

entry.title: Raisi: UNGA events provided opportunity to present Iran’s views
entry.summary: Upon returning home, Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi says his participation in the 77th session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA) provided an opportunity to present the Islamic Republic’s views to the world body and shed light on the problems facing human societies.

entry.title: Iran intel forces foil terror bomb attacks in Tabriz amid riots
entry.summary: Iranian intelligence forces have thwarted an attempt by terrorists to carry out bombings in the northwestern city of Tabriz amid a series of violent riots gripping several provinces in recent days.

entry.title: Live Update: Russia’s “Special Operation” in Ukraine; Day 213
entry.summary: Russia, wary of NATO’s eastward expansion, began a military campaign in Ukraine on February 24 after the Western-leaning Kiev government turned a deaf ear to Moscow’s calls for its neighbor to maintain its neutrality. In the middle of the mayhem, Moscow and Kiev are trying to hammer out a peaceful solution to the conflict. Follow the latest about the Russia-Ukraine conflict here:

entry.title: Iran Army condemns rioters, vows to stand by police in defending nation
entry.summary: Iran’s Army condemns the recent acts of vandalism against public property and disruption of public security by rioters, pledging that it stands by its comrades in the Police Force to help foil the enemy plots and restore calm.

entry.title: Dozens of Religious Freedom Groups Urge Blinken to Designate Nigeria 'Country of Particular Concern'
entry.summary: Religious freedom advocates and organizations from around the world are calling on the U.S. State Department to designate Nigeria as a country of particular concern.

entry.title: 'More Big, Meaningful Leaps': Bishop TD Jakes Announces Faith-Based Content Streaming Soon on Amazon
entry.summary: Bishop T.D. Jakes has announced that for the first-time ever his inspiring messages will be available to audiences worldwide to stream through Amazon services.

entry.title: 'Cities Covered in the Glory of God': Christians Unite Worldwide for '10 Days of Awe' Prayer Event
entry.summary: Thousands of churches in the United States and in 43 other countries around the world will participate in the 18th annual "10 Days", an organized global prayer event slated for Sept. 25 through Oct. 5.

entry.title: Iran 'Hijab' Protests Grow After Woman's Murder, Possibly Threaten Islamist Regime
entry.summary: Protestors are filling the streets throughout Iran following the recent death of a woman in police custody. The demonstrations are the latest sign of widespread discontent with the Islamic regime.

entry.title: Iranians hold rallies nationwide to condemn violent riots
entry.summary: Iranians hold demonstrations across the country to condemn the recent deadly riots that have hit several cities, with elements behind the violence launching attacks on security forces, public property, and sanctities.

entry.title: President Raisi meets Armenian PM, stresses regional stability
entry.summary: President Raisi of Iran, in a meeting with Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan in New York on Thursday, emphasized that the sovereignty of countries must be respected and any changes in the political geography of the region should be barred.

entry.title: Armenia and Azerbaijan accuse each other of voilating ceasefire
entry.summary: Armenian and Azerbaijani militaries have accused each other of ceasefire violations on border on Friday morning.

entry.title: Moscow-Held Regions of Ukraine in 'Sham' Vote to Join Russia
entry.summary: Voting began Friday in Moscow-held regions of Ukraine on referendums to become part of Russia, Russian-backed officials there said.The Kremlin-orchestrated referendums, which have been widely denounced by Ukraine and the West as shams without any legal force, are seen as a step toward annexing the territories by Russia.

entry.title: Iran’s judiciary chief orders speedy action against ‘rioters’
entry.summary: Iranian Judiciary Chief Gholamhossein Mohseni Ejei has ordered a swift action to deal with 'rioters' to maintain peace and security across the country after several days of protests following the death of a young Iranian woman who police confirm had a heart attack in custody.

entry.title: Judiciary official: Iranian citizens in US custody not in good condition
entry.summary: Two Iranian nationals, who are under arrest in the United States, have been experiencing unfavorable conditions for one year, Secretary of Iran’s High Council for Human Rights Kazem Gharibabadi says.

entry.title: Saturday's 'March for the Martyrs' Renews Awareness for Plight of Persecuted Christians
entry.summary: On September 24, Christians from across the country will meet up in Washington, D.C., for March for the Martyrs 2022, an annual event designed to bring attention to the growing crisis of religious persecution around the globe and to bring Christians together to pray for their suffering brothers and sisters.

entry.title: 'Escalation in the War on Free Speech': PayPal Freezes Accounts of UK's Free Speech Union Founder
entry.summary: The founder of a free speech group in the United Kingdom is speaking out after his PayPal accounts were shut down after the company accused him of violating its policies. He says no specific policies were cited though.

entry.title: 'We Could Hear Their Screaming': China's Genocidal War on Faith
entry.summary: China is using every tool at its disposal in its war on faith. All faiths. Anything that might compete with the communist state.
